openings.name: King's Pawn Opening
openings.description: The most popular first move in chess. Opens lines for the queen and bishop, controls the center.

openings.name: Italian Game
openings.description: One of the oldest openings. White develops quickly and targets the f7 pawn. Popular at all levels.

openings.name: Ruy Lopez (Spanish Opening)
openings.description: Named after Spanish priest Ruy López. Most respected e4 e5 opening. Used in world championships.

openings.name: Petrov's Defense (Russian Game)
openings.description: Solid defensive system. Black immediately counterattacks the e4 pawn. Very drawish at high level.

openings.name: Scotch Game
openings.description: Aggressive opening. White opens the center immediately. Popular in romantic era, revived by Kasparov.

openings.name: King's Gambit
openings.description: Romantic era favorite! White sacrifices a pawn for rapid development. Risky but exciting.

openings.name: Scandinavian Defense
openings.description: Black immediately challenges the e4 pawn. Solid but queen comes out early.

openings.name: Sicilian Defense
openings.description: Most popular defense to e4! Black fights for the center asymmetrically. Sharp and complex.

openings.name: Caro-Kann Defense
openings.description: Solid defensive system. Black prepares d5 without blocking the light-squared bishop.

openings.name: French Defense
openings.description: Solid but passive. Black builds a strong pawn chain but cramps their own pieces.

openings.name: Modern Defense
openings.description: Hypermodern approach. Black fianchettoes the bishop and attacks the center from afar.

openings.name: Pirc Defense
openings.description: Similar to Modern Defense. Black allows White to build a big center, then attacks it.

openings.name: French Defense: Rubinstein Variation
openings.description: Main line of French. White has space advantage, Black has solid structure.

openings.name: Queen's Pawn Opening
openings.description: Second most popular first move. More positional than e4. Controls center, develops queenside.

openings.name: Queen's Gambit
openings.description: Not really a gambit! Black can't hold the pawn. Classic opening, popular at all levels.

openings.name: Queen's Gambit Declined
openings.description: Solid defense. Black maintains central pawn, prepares to develop. Very reliable.

openings.name: Queen's Gambit Declined: Semi-Slav
openings.description: Complex and sharp. Black's setup is very flexible with multiple plans available.

openings.name: Grünfeld Defense
openings.description: Hypermodern! Black allows White's big center, then attacks it. Bobby Fischer's favorite!

openings.name: King's Indian Defense
openings.description: Fighting opening! Black allows White the center, then launches kingside attack. Kasparov loved this.

openings.name: Nimzo-Indian Defense
openings.description: Hypermodern masterpiece! Black pins the knight and controls e4. Incredibly sophisticated.

openings.name: English Opening
openings.description: Flexible and subtle. Transposes to many structures. Popular at top level.

openings.name: Réti Opening
openings.description: Hypermodern classic. White develops first, controls center later. Very flexible.

openings.name: Sicilian: Closed Variation
openings.description: Less theoretical than Open Sicilian. White avoids main lines and plays for kingside attack.

openings.name: Sicilian: Najdorf Variation
openings.description: The Rolls-Royce of the Sicilian! Bobby Fischer's and Garry Kasparov's weapon. Incredibly sharp.

openings.name: Sicilian: Dragon Variation
openings.description: Named for the dragon-shaped pawn structure. Both sides attack opposite sides. Razor sharp!

openings.name: Slav Defense
openings.description: Rock-solid defense. Black supports d5 and keeps the light-squared bishop free. Very reliable.

openings.name: Indian Game
openings.description: General category for hypermodern defenses. Black develops first, controls center later.

openings.name: Center Game
openings.description: Rare but aggressive. White opens the center immediately. Somewhat dubious.

openings.name: Bishop's Opening
openings.description: Quiet development. White aims for the Italian without committing the knight yet.

openings.name: Latvian Gambit
openings.description: Dubious gambit! Black counterattacks immediately. Unsound but trappy.

openings.name: Polish Opening (Orangutan)
openings.description: Eccentric! Named after orangutan at NY zoo. Surprise weapon but theoretically questionable.
